title.narrative: COVID-19 Response for Vulnerable Displaced Communities in Mindanao

description.narrative: IOM is providing life-saving assistance to internally displaced persons (IDPs) and returnees in the Philippines. In particular, IOM is ensuring that at-risk communities, including IDPs and returnees, are better prepared to COVID-19 through improved access to water, sanitation and hygiene (WASH) by constructing and maintaining key WASH and COVID-19 preparedness facilities, as well as providing critical equipment for safer cold chain management and promoting hygiene and awareness-raising in displacement sites. In addition, IOM aims at meeting the most urgent WASH and shelter needs of persons in vulnerable situations through cash and in-kind assistance. Through this approach, the project contributes to the long-term goal that regional and community preparedness and resilience of Mindanao is improved for potential future pandemics, as the socio-economic and physical impact of COVID-19 on at-risk communities in Mindanao is mitigated.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform

Strengthening of Comprehensive and Multisectoral Risk Management to Reduce Livelihoods Vulnerability of Communities Exposed to Multiple Natural and Man-Made Threats and Hidden Risks, Correlating Peri-Urban and Rural Areas in Bolivia

description.narrative: Through this project, IOM in Bolivia contributes through the generation of evidence in two prioritized municipalities in the Chiquitanía region of Bolivia. In coordination with FAO, the Vice-Ministry of Civil Defense and authorities, a study is being developed which identifies the needs of the displaced and migrant population; explores the effect of migration from other regions in the prioritized municipalities; identifies the potential for migration from the prioritized municipalities, given the current circumstances related to climate change and environmental damage and the socioeconomic effects of the COVID-19 pandemic; and assesses the level of integration of migration into existing emergency prevention, preparedness and response policies. The evidence generated contributes to strengthening the capacities of local actors to address migration and displacement during emergency risk management, in order to strengthen the resilience of communities.

title.narrative: Technical Capacity Building of Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation in Return and Reintegration

description.narrative: This project builds the technical capacity of the Afghan Ministry of Refugees and Repatriation (MoRR) on information management through the development and roll out of the Afghan Returnee Information System (ARIS) at four major border crossing points with Iran and Pakistan. This will facilitate the registration of all returning Afghans from which returnee certificates are issued, which then grants access to additional rights inclusive of land allocation schemes. IOM also supports the development of a reintegration referral mechanism at the provincial level in 12 provinces of high return from the initial phase now scaled up to 25 total provinces. IOM has established Reintegration Information Centers (RICs) to carry out secondary reintegration registration. The collected information is presented at monthly Provincial Reintegration Committee (PRC) meetings- multi-stakeholder forums attended by government agencies, UN and NGO partners to provide assistance and referrals to returnees. Given the COVID-19 pandemic a top up funding amount has been given to for migration health and DTM components under the original grant to address health screening/surveillance at points of entry, Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE), and continuity of basic primary health care services to underserved and marginalized migrant populations.

title.narrative: Capacity Building in Migration and Border Management in Guinea (CBMBM)

description.narrative: The overall goal of the project is to promote state and human security in Guinea by supporting law enforcement agencies to be more effective, accountable, and inclusive. Up to 4 border posts will be renovated or built and equipped with radios in the targeted areas. Through a series of capacity building activities, law enforcement agents will be trained to detect fraudulent travel documents, identify suspicious cases, and aware of the need to protect migrants. A comprehensive border assessment will be produced. Data and information on cross-border migration will be collected and analyzed by the border posts equipped with advanced data collecting system such as the Migration Information Data Analysis System and the installation of Flow Monitoring Points. Border agents will receive several trainings on data collection, use of data protection and privacy. The Government of Guinea will have increased capacity to collect, manage and analyse information on cross-border movement and develop evidence-based migration policies, as well as capacities to adapt their work to the COVID-19 context.

title.narrative: Mekong Region: Responding to Cross-Border Mobility Challenges at Points of Entry During the COVID-19 Outbreak

description.narrative: This project seeks to contribute to effective control of COVID-19 transmission across the Greater Mekong Region countries (i.e. Cambodian, Myanmar, Lao People's Democratic Republic, Viet Nam and Thailand). Its main focus is to target points of entry (PoEs) by enhancing capacity of border officials, reducing risks at PoEs and supporting vulnerable migrants in order to ensure safe, regular and humane migration. The project builds on three interrelated components to be implemented across all target countries including (1) procurement and distribution of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) for relevant frontline immigration officials and health staff at the PoE, according to WHO Standards and national guidelines; (2) capacity development for immigration authorities to implement health-compliant border procedures; and (3) information, education and communication material for migrants. In addition, intervention on special measures for migrants in immigration detention centres will be implemented in Thailand, where IOM Thailand current works to improve the situation of vulnerable migrants who are placed in detention centres operated by the Royal Thai Government.

title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Immediate Response to COVID-19 Pandemic for Effective Border Management in Nigeria

description.narrative: IOM in anticipation of the opening of the airspaces, proposes to equip the selected points of entries (PoEs) with necessary personal protective equipment (PPE) and other tools necessary for adequate border management through a public health emergency lens. In line with the National COVID-19 Multi-Sectorial Pandemic Response Plan's pillar on PoEs, IOM seeks to strengthen and increase surveillance at PoEs, including capacity building of the relevant PoE entities. The Nigeria Centre for Disease Control has in this Response Plan detailed the type of PPEs and materials that the Port Health Services (PHS) and the Nigeria Immigration Service (NIS) would need to adequately protect themselves while in the line of duty as front-line workers. Central to infection, prevention and control (IPC) is the strengthening of weak water sanitation and hygiene (WASH) systems at PoEs, in some instances, these are non-existent and will need to be established. WASH systems play an important role in IPC, and it is important to ensure that PoEs are decked out with the necessary infrastructure to ensure that IPC is effectively conducted. To complement all the aforementioned interventions, IOM will seek to provide the PHS with computers to enable them to establish electronic system for adequate border management.

title.narrative: Support of Points of Entries into Cameroon through the Reinforcement of the Border Management System in its Attempt to Tackle the Transmission of COVID-19

description.narrative: The intervention will seek to improve the capacity of the border management system in its effort to mitigate the propagation of COVID-19. Following assessments at points of entries (PoEs), it was determined that the border agents lack the requirement equipment (handwashing facilities) and supplies (gloves, eye protection, facemasks) to properly process the movements of merchandise and travelers. Additionally, there is an urgent need of accurate data on events related to COVID-19 in the three targeted provinces bordering Cameroon and Central African Republic. Even though these borders are opened for only commercial purposes, Chadian nationals are still entering Chad and quarantined at PoEs for two weeks where they do not have the support to meet their daily needs and are forced to discreetly leave their quarantine locations. The project intends to support the government in information management by conducting data collection mainly on observed flow at PoEs, profiles and needs of quarantined individuals, preventive measures in place at PoEs and COVID-19 related knowledge at PoEs.

title.narrative: Strengthening Fiji's Border Management Capacity

description.narrative: Fiji is a relatively high mobility country, having the second highest number of immigrants in the Pacific. The Fiji Department of Immigration (DoI) is the main government agency responsible for overseeing immigration and border management efforts in the country. The objective of the project is to contribute to the Government of Fiji achieving strengthened migration governance through enhancing border security and travel facilitation, which aligns with targets under Fiji’s 5-year National Development Plan. The proposed project will provide technical support, including capacity development and training on process improvement, policy development, data sharing, administrative streamlining, and mentoring. It will also assist the DoI in reviewing its response to the COVID-19 pandemic and identifying opportunities for improvements and better coordination with other government entities such as the Ministry of Health and Medical Services. Through this technical support, the project aims to increase Fiji’s capacity to effectively manage its borders while improving national security and economic opportunities for the country.

title.narrative: Nigerian Immigration Service - Training Strategy Implementation - Phase II

description.narrative: Over the past years, IOM has supported Nigerian Immigration Service (NIS) in developing and updating the NIS training strategy which aims to institutionalise the common training approach across the agency and boost its overall capacity in fulfilling its mandate defined in the 2015 Immigration Act. The first phase of the project successfully contributed to the implementation of the training strategy. Building on the outcome of Phase I and responding to the current pandemic, the proposed project aims to update the training curriculum and the learning management system, scale up the training programme to reach a larger number of NIS officers as well as enhance joint training efforts with the National Agency for the Prohibition of Trafficking in Persons (NAPTIP) with considerations to establishing COVID-19 control measures during trainings. This project primarily aims to enhance NIS and NAPTIP capacity to regularise processing of individuals passing international borders by applying legal, operational, and technical tools, and best practices in border management.

title.narrative: Enhancing Dominica’s Border Management Capacity

description.narrative: Dominica is known to be a point of transit for a significant number of Haitian nationals en route to the French territories of Guadeloupe and/or Martinique, however, there is little information available about the nature, size and scope of undocumented migrants arriving to or transiting through Dominica. In addition, records of exits and entries are not available at all border control posts and, hence, the government has indicated its need to improve immigration infrastructure and train border management officials. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic, this need has become even more of a priority. This project will strengthen the border management capacity of the Government of Dominica and contribute to the prevention of irregular migration. Customised training will be delivered to immigration officers on immigration and border management topics including document examination and counter smuggling will be facilitated and will be followed by the development of a final guidance document. In addition, essential equipment will be installed at specific border control points and relevant staff will be trained to use the devices.

title.narrative: Open South America

description.narrative: The project aims to strengthen the capacity of MERCOSUR governments to facilitate orderly, regular and responsible migration and mobility in South America amid and after the COVID- 19 pandemic. This will be achieved by providing MERCOSUR government officials with accessible, reliable and timely information on human mobility restrictions, permissions, health and safety measures for their use in drafting migration policy and coordinating additional measures and interventions in the region. In particular, the project will develop and launch a “Sudamerica Abierta” platform and mobile application, which will contain updated information on human mobility restrictions, health and safety measures in all MERCOSUR State Parties and Associated States to facilitate intraregional human mobility. The project will also draft and validate Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) to ensure the governments capacity to collect information and maintain the platform long-term. The project will also train key government officials in each participating country on the use of the platform and develop a communication campaign in Spanish, Portuguese and English and carry out a final closing event to promote the platform and mobile phone application amongst key regional stakeholders, as well as migrants, potential donors and the general public.

The JP will enhance integrated management of the states' borders and promote exchanges to better control illegal activities as well as other risks to which border communities are particularly vulnerable. Increased cooperation will reduce human trafficking and the prevalence of gender-based violence; minimize the spread of COVID-19; improve cross-border social cohesion; and protect human rights. title.narrative: Strengthening a Coordinated Response to Public Health Emergencies Along Ghana’s Borders

description.narrative: This project seeks to ensure a coordinated response at Ghana’s land borders to COVID-19 and other public health emergencies. This will be achieved through ensuring border officials have increased capacity and operational guidance to ensure a coordinated response to health emergencies at land borders. Activities include a three-day Training of Trainers (ToT) workshop for 16 officials western and north western borders, a three-day ToT workshop for 16 officials from eastern and north eastern borders, and the development of training materials and standard operating procedures on the response to and management of COVID-19 and other public health emergencies. The ToT workshops will create a core of national trainers on public health emergency response across the country who, in turn, will carry out cascade training workshops based on resources available. This will precipitate positive long-term sustainable effects towards ensuring coordinated responses to public health emergencies at land borders in Ghana. The ToTs would also include sessions on risk communication and protection of vulnerable persons to ensure that the public health response at the national land borders is carried out through engagement with border communities and is responsive to protection needs of vulnerable persons on the move.

title.narrative: Strengthening Border Management to Mitigate the Risk of Terrorism from Land and Maritime Borders in the Context of COVID-19

description.narrative: The overall objective of the proposed intervention is to enhance border security and national stability in light of the COVID19 context, through an improved response and strengthened coordination among border management agencies to effectively combat terrorism threats and other transnational organized crime. OM aims to support the Government of Uganda, through close coordination with the border management agencies of Immigration, Security, Customs and Health to inter-alia, improve preparedness and identification of terrorist groups through points of entry and develop capacities against terrorist attempts to launder money. IOM Uganda has previously engaged in several initiatives such as joint training activities, provision of border management equipment such as vehicles and ICT support. However, with the effects of COVID-19 and a shift in priorities to health, states require now, more than before, an increase of border security efforts through a dedicated border management project aimed at counterterrorism.

IOM will build the capacity of frontline officers at the border to incorporate necessary health border and mobility management practices during the COVID-19 pandemic, while also enhancing infrastructural capacity, such as accommodation facility/ies equipped with solar panels, personal protective equipment and other equipment as needed, and dedicated spaces for female officers which will also allow to increase the number of deployed female officers.

This will be achieved by supporting Border Authorities with appropriate infrastructure and equipment, including personal protective equipment, while also training staff present at points of entry to screen, detect and safely handle, isolate, and refer suspected cases of COVID-19 and other communicable diseases, in line with IOM’s Health Border and Mobility Management (HBMM) framework.

title.narrative: Strengthening COVID-19 Response in Timor-Leste's Border Communities Phase II (SCRIT-LBC Phase II)

description.narrative: Cross-border human mobility has been drastically impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic, with border closures and travel restrictions of unparalleled scale. As restrictions begin to ease and governments around the world contemplate removing mobility restrictions and reopening borders, the Government of Timor-Leste needs to take into account how to effectively manage cross-border mobility while safeguarding public health. Timor-Leste is characterized by dynamic migration flows. It is experiencing increased rates of international migration – both regular and irregular, facilitated by the porous borders with Indonesia. Following the detection of the first case of Covid-19 in Timor-Leste, the Government of Timor-Leste has been making tremendous efforts in preventing the spread of the virus, but these efforts can be undermined if effective preventive measures are not in place at ports of entry and border crossing points. Guided by the Health, Border & Mobility Management (HBMM) framework, the proposed project contributes to the government of Timor-Leste’s efforts to prevent the risks of cross-border disease transmission, taking into consideration mobility dynamics and cross border movements through capacity building to frontline border officials, flow monitoring for evidence based health interventions and improved border management response, and awareness raising among border communities and mobile population.

description.narrative: IOM has developed training curricula and aids to enhance member states officials’ capacities to continue to work and to adapt their operational practices to the context of COVID-19 response at points of entry (PoE). This training curriculum draws upon the latest IOM and WHO reference materials, including International Health Regulations (IHR) (2005) on PoE preparedness and response. In order to increase capacities for Border Agency personnel to be able to manage the current pandemic, a migration training curriculum will be developed that will utilize materials for remote training, as in-person support is not possible. This will be done by creating virtual classroom environments or self-paced e-learning courses, available on an online platform. Promotional material will also be designed on the correct process for dealing with the current COVID-19 pandemic, the correct use of protective equipment and how to minimize risk.

title.narrative: Supporting Evidence-Based Policies and Programmes in the Context of Cross-Border Mobility in Cambodia and Viet Nam

description.narrative: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Governments of Cambodia and Viet Nam imposed border closures and mobility restrictions. As a result, the economies in border areas between Viet Nam and Cambodia have been severely disrupted, with a significant impact on border communities, small-scale cross-border traders, as well as daily and seasonal migrants who earn a living through cross-border economic activities. The overall objective of the project is to support the Governments of Cambodia and Viet Nam to enhance the formulation and implementation of evidence-based policies and programmes in the context of cross-border mobility. The project will develop capacities of the government officials to regularly collect, update and analyse comprehensive data to inform the planning, coordination and implementation of national policy and programming on migration and human mobility. The project objective will be achieved through the realization of two interlinked and interdependent project outcomes: i) Information and data analysis will be regularly utilized to inform migration policy decisions and programme design; and ii) Interagency and cross-order cooperation will be strengthened through bilateral exchange on relevant policy information and harmonization of procedures for reopening borders between the two countries.

Through a regional analysis of COVID-19 impact on Border Management in Sahel region, it will improve understanding of common regional issues on border management. In addition to collecting and analyzing information, pilot activities such as training activities and community engagement activities will be implemented as part of this project. Thus, this project will provide the opportunity for IOM and JICA to collect all essential information on the realities and gaps at points of entries (PoE) and along the borders and the result of the analysis will be used in formulating new technical or financial cooperation projects to address common regional issues on border management.

title.narrative: Empowering Migrant Worker Households and Strengthening Capacities at Points of Entry in Indonesia

description.narrative: IOM aim to enhance Government of Indonesia’s response in addressing the health and socio-economic impacts of COVID-19 throughout the country. It will contribute so through the two-fold objectives, as the following: Objective 1: To strengthen the Government of Indonesia’s efforts in mitigating the health risks and socio-economic impact of COVID-19 on Indonesian migrant worker households. Objective 2: To strengthen the Government of Indonesia’s COVID-19 preparedness and response measures at points of entry (PoEs) in Indonesia, including international airports, seaports, and ground crossings.Under the first objective, IOM will work in close collaboration with the National Agency for the Protection of Indonesian Migrant Workers (BP2MI), as the main mandated government institution responsible for the protection and empowerment of Indonesian migrant workers and their families. Under the second objective, IOM will focus in strengthening COVID-19 response, through improved infection prevention and control measures, as well as disease surveillance at the PoEs. In executing the proposed response under this Objective, IOM will closely work with the Ministry of Health and the Directorate General of Immigration, under the Ministry of Law and Human Rights.

title.narrative: Kazakhstan: Enhancing Migration Management and Labour Mobility Governance

description.narrative: This project aims to support the Government of Kazakhstan's efforts to institute good internal migration governance and empower migrants and their families as development actors by better addressing the specific obstacles faced by youth and women in integrating into the labour market and accessing sustainable livelihoods. The project is developed in support of the Government's priorities set out in the long-term strategic planning 'Enbek' South - North Internal Relocation Programme, which facilitates internal migration. The outcome of the project focuses on producing and implementing evidence-based reforms to the Enbek Programme. These reforms include: the development of socioeconomic vulnerability criteria; capacity-building for Government stakeholders on monitoring and evaluation, to support evidence-based reforms; and the development of middle- and long-term response plans for COVID-19 impact on programme beneficiaries. The findings of the project will be integrated into the nation-wide comprehensive State Migration Policy Concept (2021-2025).

title.narrative: Phase I - Strengthening Kuwaiti Governmental Efforts to Promote Ethical Recruitment of Foreign Workers

description.narrative: This project will contribute to strengthening Kuwait’s Global Positioning pillar under the Kuwait National Development Plan (KNDP) 2035, particularly in the context of secondary COVID-19 response, by promoting national mechanisms on good migration governance to facilitate inward flow of labour mobility at all skill levels and to improve their migration experience. Phase One of STRENGTH will promote ethical recruitment and enable national agencies to update the evidence-based policy and programming thereby increasing national efforts to improve the institutional governance of foreign workers. These updates will address the defaults in the system which have been revealed during the COVID-19 crisis where thousands of foreign workers have been exploited by visa traders. The updates will include the introduction and rollout of the International Recruitment Integrity System (IRIS) as a social compliance scheme intended to promote ethical recruitment among employers and recruitment agencies and the skeleton of a mobile application connecting employers-employees-labor inspectors to regulate employment relationships.

title.narrative: Strengthening Labour Migration Framework in Albania

description.narrative: This project aims to contribute to assessing and strengthening the labour migration framework in Albania through specific activities focusing on data collection and analysis. In order to achieve this, the project will ensure that the government has increased capacity to collect, analyse and produce comprehensive, consistent and gender-sensitive data and has the necessary resources to develop long-term labour migration policies and to promote ethical recruitment practices in the country. The main activities to be implemented include the development of a training module on migration data and statistics for government officials; conducting of an assessment of the labour market needs in select countries of destination and their impact on the Albanian labour force, with an analysis of how COVID-19 has affected these flows; drafting of a study on predictive modelling of the migration impact on the Albanian workforce and skills development needs; and, establishment of national guidelines on ethical recruitment of migrant workers, for their further inclusion into the national labour migration policy framework. Through capacity-building, research and policy activities, the project will build an evidence-base and provide the Government with the tools needed to improve labour migration management and ethical recruitment practices in the country.

title.narrative: Strengthening Data-informed and Migrant-centred Migration Management Frameworks in India

description.narrative: The Government of India (GoI) and the Ministry of External Affairs (MEA) are invested in strengthening the availability of comprehensive labour migration data to facilitate gainful labour migration for aspiring migrants and support national socioeconomic recovery. The project's objective is to contribute to improving access to labour migration opportunities for aspiring Indian migrants through strengthened migration management frameworks. The project will conduct a thorough needs assessment of existing data gaps and needs, develop and equip the MEA with a comprehensive migration data management strategy, and pilot communication materials and surveys to inform migrant workers on the benefits of submitting data voluntarily. The project will also conduct and equip the MEA with research on post-COVID-19 emerging labour markets in Northern and Eastern Europe and the elderly care-giving sector, and facilitate bilateral migration dialogues and sector-specific consultations with key stakeholders.

title.narrative: Asia Region: Protecting Migrant Workers in COVID-19 Socio-Economic Recovery by Engaging with Public and Private Sectors to Strengthen Ethical Recruitment and Employment Practices

description.narrative: Migrant workers from the Philippines and Viet Nam are among the largest groups in Macao Special Administrative Region (SAR), China. Despite limited availability of recent studies and research on migrant workers in Macao SAR, China, there are reports of certain risks for migrant workers in recruitment and employment practices including being subject to high recruitment fees and receiving lower wages than local workers. Furthermore, border closures and travel restrictions during the COVID-19 pandemic have adversely impacted the tourism-dependent economy, triggering job losses of migrant workers. The overall objective of the proposed project is to contribute to the protection of migrant workers from the Philippines and Viet Nam in COVID-19 socio-economic recovery by strengthening the implementation of ethical recruitment and employment practices. This will be achieved through engaging labour authorities in countries of origin and destination to strengthen services and response to migrant workers' needs at varying stages of their migration journey; working with private sector labour actors and employers to promote compliance with national regulation and commit to meet international ethical recruitment standards; and improving information access for migrant workers to better inform their migration-related decisions and strengthening support from the civil society, migrant worker led organizations and Migrant Resource Centres.

title.narrative: Preventing Forced Labour and Countering Irregular Migration in the Russian Federation

description.narrative: The project aims at supporting the Government of the Russian Federation in countering irregular employment, forced labour and human trafficking among migrants, while addressing the needs and vulnerabilities of the most vulnerable ones. The project's objective is two-fold. It will review and update the policy standards in the area of regular migration and employment thus reaching the outcome of improved evidence-based migration policy promoting regular migration channels, regular employment and managed recruitment of migrant workers in CIS and EEU member-states. It will address the needs of migrants, stranded due to mobility restrictions imposed to contain the spread of COVID-19 within the outcome to mitigate the risks and vulnerabilities of migrants associated with forced labour and human trafficking, as well as COVID-19.

title.narrative: Asia: Enhancing Corporate Responsibility in Eliminating Slavery and Trafficking in Asia (CREST Project)

description.narrative: To address challenges that migrant workers face amid COVID-19 and promote the protection of migrant workers across Asia in response to COVID-19, the International Organization for Migration (IOM) carries out a series of interlinked regional and country-level interventions following a whole of government and society approach. This project builds on IOM’s larger regional COVID-19 response outlined in IOM’s Strategic Response and Recovery Plan (SRRP) 2021, the Framework for the Intermediate Socio-economic Response to COVID-19 and implemented as part as part of IOM’s regional Corporate Responsibility in Eliminating Slavery and Trafficking Project in Asia (CREST) with support from the Development and Cooperation Section of the Swedish Embassy in Thailand and in collaboration with private sector partners. Leveraging the project’s ongoing initiatives, robust and geographically diverse partnerships and knowledge, activities will be carried out in three countries of destination, Hong Kong SAR, China, Malaysia and Thailand, and two countries of origin: the Philippines and Viet Nam. The project also aims at strengthening the role of civil societies in directly assisting migrant worker communities affected by COVID-19. As such, IOM partners with the Migrant Forum in Asia for implementation in five additional countries of origin: Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Nepal and Sri Lanka.

title.narrative: Development of Local Capacities for Strengthening Primary Health Care Services on Sexual and Reproductive Health, Mental Health, Prevention of Psychoactive Substance Use, Nutritional Health-Phase II

description.narrative: This project aims to strengthen local capacities to improve effective access to comprehensive primary health care services, and to design and implement an extramural and intercultural strategy of primary health care. This strategy will promote and provide health services with a gender and equity approach, promoting community and intersectoral action for the construction of scenarios peacekeepers. The strategy will also provide training to 52 peasant or indigenous leaders as public health assistants. Finally, the project will implement a community-based results monitoring system with an intercultural approach. The project will have an emphasis on the exercise of sexual and reproductive rights, mental health, prevention of the consumption of psychoactive substances, attention to children and malnutrition in the 26 municipalities in which the Territorial Training and Reincorporation Spaces-ETCR are located. Additionally, activities are included to support the hospitals and communities affected by the COVID-19 in delivery of personal protection elements for the prevention of contagion of human talent in health, support for the provision of health services and epidemiological surveillance.

title.narrative: Supporting the Government of Viet Nam in Strengthening Public Health Emergency Preparedness and Response for Vietnamese Migrants Abroad and Potential Migrants

description.narrative: The overall objective of the proposed project is to contribute to effective public health emergency preparedness and response by the Government of Viet Nam along the mobility continuum. In order to better understand challenges facing Vietnamese migrants abroad in accessing accurate information as well as healthcare during public health crises, the project will undertake a study which targets Vietnamese migrants living in major countries of destination, as well as a broad range of governmental and non-governmental stakeholders. The results of the study will enable the Government of Vietnam to identify key issues and develop recommendations for areas of prioritized action. The study will also inform a gender-sensitive guideline to be developed by the Government of Viet Nam on ensuring health of migrants during public health emergencies along the mobility continuum. The project will create country profiles of up-to-date health and immigration regulations including COVID-19 related measures. A training of trainers will also be delivered for Vietnamese recruitment agencies to improve their knowledge and skills on better advising potential and departing migrants as well as migrants abroad in the context of public health emergencies.

The project will focus on facilitating the access to quality health services for vulnerable migrants and improving the protection of rights of stranded migrants affected by COVID-19 crisis, in particular, vulnerable female migrants. title.narrative: IOM Crisis Response Platform
Pre-Departure Medical Services for Canada-Bound Refugees

description.narrative: As of April 2017, the IRCC introduced a reimbursement scheme for Pre-Departure Medical Screening of Canada-bound refugees as a part of the Interim Federal Health Program (IFHP). The programme operates through Medavie Blue Cross, a Canadian not-for-profit company. IFHP extends coverage to the following health services: 1) immigration medical examination; 2) vaccinations; 3) management of conditions of public health importance and safety (tuberculosis, syphilis, HIV and mental disorders); 4) outbreak management and 5) medical assistance for travel. Recently, COVID-19-related measures were added as outbreak management activities.

Through this component, IOM will build the capacities of the government institutions working at the border (i.e. frontline workers), to develop and ensure sustainability of the PMM intervention, the first of its kind in Rwanda. title.narrative: Strengthening Capacities for Comprehensive Containment, Mitigation and Surveillance in Response to COVID-19 in Costa Rican Northern Border Areas

description.narrative: The recent confirmation of an increasing number of cases of Covid-19 in Costa Rica underlines the compelling need for local action to contain the spread and mitigate the effects of this global pandemic. Due to massive flows of migrants, the Central American region is at a particularly high risk for disease transmission throughout its borders and within its communities. Costa Rica is a major destination and transit country for migrants from a variety of locations, including Nicaragua, Venezuela, Guatemala, Honduras, El Salvador, African, and South Asian Countries. Since close contact with local communities is unlikely to be avoided, disease surveillance and control among local and migrant populations is critical. Any efforts to curtail the spread of epidemic-prone diseases must consider systems of human traffic and migration as a critical realm for intervention and be designed to be replicable throughout the Central American region.

title.narrative: Enhancing the National COVID-19 Response Capacity in Iraq

description.narrative: IOM Iraq will contribute to enhancing the national response capacity to COVID-19 through targeted interventions aligned to OFDA's health, protection and water, sanitation, and hygiene sectors. In particular, IOM will provide technical support to the Government of Iraq to strengthen the national response to COVID-19 through conducting various types of trainings for the ministry of health; provide risk communication activities and engage with communities on COVID-19 awareness; reinforce disease surveillance; support primary healthcare facilities and health workers on identification and response to COVID-19; promote hand hygiene practices; strengthen hygiene promotion measures in camps and informal settlements and strengthen protection environment and provide psychosocial support services in affected communities.

title.narrative: Prepare, Prevent, Protect: Mitigating the Destabilizing Socio-Economic Impact of COVID-19 on Most Vulnerable and Conflict-Prone Communities in Mindanao

description.narrative: With the Philippines anticipating cycles of high transmission rates of COVID-19 and the differential implementation of community quarantine across the country until the pandemic subsides, marginalized social groups and internally displaced persons are likely to be disproportionately impacted by restrictive interventions. In response to these challenges, IOM Philippines will adopt its “Prepare, Prevent, Protect” approach to mitigate the destabilizing socio-economic impact of COVID-19 on most vulnerable and conflict-prone communities in Mindanao.

title.narrative: Timor-Leste COVID-19 Response - Laboratory Equipment Procurement Support (COVID-LAB)

description.narrative: Building on IOM’s current ‘Community-Based Active Case Detection and Management of Tuberculosis in Timor-Leste, the project proposes to contribute to mitigating the transmission of COVID-19 in Timor-Leste. Through this project IOM will support the Ministry of Health to strengthen the capacity of the National Health Laboratory to respond to the COVID-19 outbreak and maintain existing essential laboratory services. IOM will use its established global procurement system to ensure that the National Health Laboratory have the necessary equipment to detect and confirm COVID-19.

title.narrative: Primary Healthcare and MHPSS Service Provision for IDP Returnees in Gedeo, West Guji and East Wollega Zones in Oromia and SNNPR Regions (Health and MHPSS)

description.narrative: IOM continues to deliver quality primary healthcare services, including mental health and psychosocial support, by deploying mobile health and nutrition teams to internally displaced person returns sites that have limited to no healthcare service access. The proposed intervention will be implemented in West Guji, East Wollega and Gedeo zones in Woredas of Kercha, Guto Gida and Yirgacheffe Woreda and Yirgacheffe town respectively. In addition to the provision of primary healthcare services, this project will be responding to the currently ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, index case confirmed in Ethiopia.

provider-org.narrative: UNITED NATIONS OFFICE FOR THE COORDINATION OF HUMANITARIAN AFFAIRS (OCHA) - Country Based Pooled Funds

title.narrative: Emergency Assistance- Country-Level Funding- IOM 2020

description.narrative: IOM is contributing to the overall objective of the WHO's COVID-19 Global Strategic Preparedness and Response Plan (SRP) to halt further transmission of COVID-19, and mitigate the impact of the outbreak, including the social impact. IOM has also launched its own COVID-19 Appeal on the 20 March to guide and coordinate IOM global response with government, partners and donors, itself a component of the UN Global Humanitarian Response Plan. Cox's Bazar District continues to host more than 855,000 Rohingya refugees in camps with a total area of approximately 24 square kilometers. The high population density, in combination with an already uncertain health profile, puts these populations at a heightened risk of community transmission and threatens to overwhelm the already overburdened local medical system and infrastructure in a very short period. In order to properly address the health and socioeconomic issues caused by COVID-19, humanitarian access to the camp is critical to the well-being of affected populations and the success of humanitarian interventions. The proposed project has two main elements; IOM's Cox's Bazar COVID-19 Response and site maintenance engineering.
